China b SEU-FEI Nano-Pico Center, Key Laboratory of MEMS of Ministry of Education, School of Electrical Science and Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China SEU-FEI Nano-Pico Center, Key Laboratory of MEMS of Ministry of Education, School of Electrical Science and Engineering Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China bSEU-FEI Nano-Pico Center, Key Laboratory of MEMS of Ministry of Education, School of Electrical Science and Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. # These authors contributed equally to this study The highly efficient electrochemical synthesis of ammonia is regarded as a promising alternative compared to the traditional Haber-Bosch (H-B) process. However, the high-activity, low-cost, and long-term stability of electrocatalysts are still barriers to their rapid development. Herein, utilizing density functional theory (DFT), FeRu dual-atom catalyst anchored in N-doped phosphorene (FeRu@N4-P) is developed as a potential candidate for reducing inert N2 through electrocatalysis. Our results reveal that the distal and alternating pathways occur on the FeRu@N4-P with the lowest overpotential (0.29 V and 0.36 V). Moreover, we notice that there is a transformation from the alternating pathway to the enzymatic pathway for the step *NH2 NH2 + H+ + e− →*NH2+*NH3. Considering the influence of the electrolyte solution in the actual experiment, we compared the sensitivity of electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (e-NRR) catalyst to the adsorption of H, demonstrating the efficient selectivity of FeRu@N4-P. The catalysts still maintain good stability and performance at room temperature. Finally, combining the physical properties of the metal atom, Φ is chosen to as the descriptor linearly correlating to the ΔG*N2 on the catalyst. This study deepens our understanding on the e-NRR mechanism on the dual-atoms doped phosphorene and opens a new way for the design of catalyst of the N2 fixation. Graphic abstract Electrocatalytic reduction of N2 on FeRu dual-atom catalyst anchored in N-doped black phosphorene Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phosphorene Dual-atom catalyst Nitrogen reduction reaction Density functional theory Electrochemistry Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The production of ammonia (NH3) is immensely important both in agricultural as and industrial settings due to the fact that it is the source material for many products, such as fertilizers, medicines, and nitric acid [1,2]. Therefore, the exploration of new methods for ammonia synthesis is a constant area of research. Biological N2 fixation enzymes present in nature are capable of fixing atmospheric N2, the product of which is usually in the form of ammonium [3]. Inspired by biological fixation, the Haber-Bosch (H-B) process with Fe-based catalysts emerged as the mainstream of industrial ammonia synthesis. However, the harsh conditions of the H-B process, high pressure (>150 bar) and temperature (>450 °C), mean that a significant amount of energy is consumed from the burning of fossil fuels. Moreover, the yield of NH3 is not very high, just 20–30% [4,5]. To overcome the challenges associated with the H-B process, the search for ways to synthesize ammonia under mild conditions is an important research topic. Recent studies have shown that the d orbitals of metals are able to perform two different reaction mechanisms to the activation of inert N2, i.e., giving electrons or empty orbitals, which facilitates the reaction process to some extent [6,7]. So far, Ru, Rh, Au, Pt, Ni, Ti, Fe, and Cu have been widely used as reaction media for the reduction of N2 to NH3 [8–11]. However, the fact that the catalytic reaction takes place at the interface between solid and gas phases results in a low utilization of the vast majority of metal atoms. Hence, most of the atoms in bulk metals are wasted. This problem of wasted metal atoms is particularly prominent for the precious metal catalysts. How can we improve the utilization of the metal atoms for the nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR)? Can the utilization be maximized by adjusting the size of the metal catalysts? These questions have formed a basis for scientific exploration by researchers. Studies show that [12–15] with size reduction (i.e., bulk metal, nano-cluster, or single-atom), the efficiency of the catalysts is greatly improved. In particular, the ideal single-atoms can reach 100% utilization for N2 reduction. The single-atom catalysts (SACs) have been proposed due to their high atom utilization and high catalytic selectivity. For instance, Fe@-C@C3N (−0.49 V), Mo-CN (−0.42 V), Mo@Fe2P (−0.30 V), Mo@Fe3P (−0.17 V), Nb/BP (−0.25 V), W/BP (−0.19 V) and B/PC6 (−0.37 V) are highly competitive in NRR due to their ultra-low limiting potential [16–21]. Besides, multi-level descriptors, considering the valence electron number, electronegativity and the coordination environment are developed to quickly predict their catalytic performances [17]. Inevitably, the increase in surface energy drives the aggregation of single-atoms into tiny clusters, which prevents the large-scale development of single-atom catalysts. Recently, the proposal of dual-atom catalysts (DACs) is a promising strategy for atomic catalysis due to the extremely increased metal atom loadings and sites [22–24]. Therefore, DACs are a good choice for both catalytic efficiency and ease of operation. Moreover, the synergistic catalytic interaction between atoms (i.e., homo-nuclear or hetero-nuclear) is a unique feature, offering unlimited possibilities for the design of DACs. In addition, it is not only important to consider the efficiency of the catalyst. A suitable substrate that strongly interacts with the catalyst atoms is also important. Phosphorene is an ordered 2D single crystal nanosheet exfoliated from black phosphorus (BP) [25], it has a controlled direct band gap (0.3–2.0 eV), high carrier mobility (104 cm2/V·s), significant anisotropy and good biocompatibility [26]. It is a fifth main group of low-dimensional materials, has been widely used in the design of N2 reduction catalysts, due to its high specific area, good stability, tunable surface chemistry, and high electrical conductivity [27,28]. In contrast to graphene (Gra), BP itself is capable of reducing N2 to NH3 [29]. However, pristine BP has a relatively large energy barrier in the process of reduction. Therefore, the introduction of an atomic level catalyst, a DAC, which modulates the BP interface to enhance catalytic performance and lower the reaction potential, has become a possible NRR catalyst design. Moreover, transition metal-nitrogen (TM-Nx) as central catalytic sites exhibit excellent performance for NRR because they can coordinate unsaturated TM atoms and make TM atoms stable with heterogeneous N atoms. Many researchers have initiated studies of TM-Nx, and they have achieved initial breakthroughs [6,28,29]. However, current studies in this field are still mainly focused on the prerequisite of Gra and its analogues as substrate materials. For instance, FeFe@N6-Gra, CoCo@N6-Gra, Mo@Nx-BP (x = 0, 1, 2, 3), Ti@N4-Gra, Mo1(Cr1) @N3-Gra have all been reported [28–31]. For BP and its allotrope, only a few studies have been reported in this field [28,32,33]. It has been demonstrated that many transition metals, including both the non-noble metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mo) and noble metals (e.g., Au, Ag, Pd, Ru) can effectively catalyze N2 to NH3 as SACs [8-11,34-38]. However, inhibited by the intense competition of the hydrogen evolution reaction in an aqueous electrolyte, some of them, such as Fe, Mo, exhibit low faraday efficiency. The other ones, such as Au, Ag, Pd and Ru are too expensive and scarce to be used in a large-scale production. In our DACs of NRR exploration, we herein try to construct the homo-nuclear and hetero-nuclear DACs by combining both the widely used non-noble TM catalysts (Fe, Co, Ni) and the noble metal Ru of ultra-low overpotential 0.26 V to find out all the possible promising DACs as much as possible. In this article, we have focused on the NRR catalytic potentials of homo-nuclear and hetero-nuclear dual atoms anchored in N-doped phosphorene by considering the combination of Fe, Co, Ni and Ru (TM1TM1@N4-P or TM1TM2@N4-P). By comparing different both homo-nuclear and hetero-nuclear dual-atom anchored N4 nanosheet, our results reveal that the FeRu dual sites show strong chemisorption properties when the proximal N atoms of N2 are adsorbed, with end-on configuration. Further studies show that hetero-nuclear (FeRu) in the N-doped P electrocatalytic N2 reduction, the catalytic efficiency is far superior through the distal and alternating pathways with the overpotential as low as 0.29 V and 0.36 V. Compared with the surface of Ru (0001), DACs of FeRu@N4-P show the significant improvement in its performance towards N2 reduction. Facing the challenge of selectivity for the e-NRR catalyst, the adsorption of H on FeRu@N4-P is evaluated and the result shows that FeRu@N4-P is more sensitive to N2 capture. Furthermore, the binding energy and molecular dynamics calculations predict that the structure of FeRu@N4-P have good stability at room temperature. 2 Computational methods All theoretical computations were carried out using the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) based on density functional theory (DFT) using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) for the exchange correlation functional [39–41]. The electron-ion interactions were described by projector augmented wave (PAW) [42]. To consider the van der Waals interaction, we used DFT-D3 method for the correction [43], and set a vacuum thickness of more than 20 Å along the z-axis to prevent the effects of periodicity. The cut-off energy for the plane wave basis set was taken as 500 eV. To fully guarantee the accuracy of the energy and force, the convergence criteria are 10−4 eV/atom and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. The k-points in the Brillouin zone are sampled based on the Monkhorst-Pack mesh with the grid 3 × 2 × 1. In addition, Bader charge was used to analyze the number of electron transfer [44]. Furthermore, the thermal stabilities of the catalyst were investigated using molecular dynamics (DFT-MD) simulations [45,46]. The DFT-MD calculation is carried out at 300 K with a time step of 2 fs. Because the low stabilization of the intermediates caused by the solvation in NRR is small (∼ 0.1 eV), solvent effects are ignored [47]. In this article, the Binding energy (Eb) is further evaluated by following equation to describe the stability of DAC and its substrate. (1) E b = E tot − E TM 1 − E TM 2 − E N − P where Etot and EN-P are total energies of the system and N-doped P. TM1 and TM2 represent the energies of isolated atoms, which can be same or different. The formula for calculating the cohesive energy (Ecoh) in the system is as follows [48]: (2) E coh = E TM bulk − E TM Where E TM bulk and E TM represent the energy of a single metal atom in the bulk phase and an isolated one, respectively. For dual atoms, to compare with the binding energies, the summation of the two cohesive energies is defined: (3) E coh = E TM 1 bulk − E TM 1 + E TM 2 bulk − E TM 2 The adsorption energies (Eads) of N2 on the catalyst is defined as (4) E ads = E N 2 − cat − E cat − E N 2 where E N 2 − cat , Ecat, and EN2 are the energies of the N2 adsorbed on catalyst, catalyst and gaseous N2, respectively. The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model is used to describe the change in the free energy of the intermediate in the electrochemical NRR process [49,50], where the chemical potential of the H +/e − is considered to estimate half of the gaseous H2. Thus, the change of Gibbs free energy for each element step is defined as follow: (5) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + eU + Δ G pH where ΔE is the electronic energy difference, ΔEZPE and ΔS represent the zero-point energy correction and entropy change, respectively, which are obtained from the analysis of the vibration frequency of the adsorbates [51,52]. The simulated temperature condition is 298.15 K. e and U are the number of electrons transferred and the electrode potential applied, respectively. Previous studies [53,54] prove that although the Gibbs free energy increases with the increased pH, the overpotential does not change with it. Therefore, in this study the electrocatalytic reduction reaction is considered in an environment with pH = 0. Besides, the limiting potential (UL) is introduced to assess ease of occurrence of the catalytic reaction and is obtained from the following equation: (6) U L = − Δ G max / e where ΔGmax is the maximum positive value for free energy change. The overpotential is calculated by [55]: (7) η = U 0 − U L where U0 and UL is the equilibrium potential and limiting potential, respectively. The U0 of NRR vs. SHE can be calculated by the Nernst equation: U0 = U0 pH=0 – 0.06 pH [56], where U0 pH=0 is the equilibrium potential at pH = 0. Here, U0 is −0.16 V for N2 reduction. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Model and structure As we know, the chemical bond (NN) that constitutes N2 is stable and requires a high bond dissociation energy, which is very difficult to be cleaved in the natural environment. The adsorption and activation of N2 molecules on the catalyst is the prerequisite step before e-NRR, which can influence the subsequent reaction process. As shown in Fig. 1 (a-b), a widely recognized process on the initial activation of the e-NRR is that the unoccupied d orbital of the transition metal atom will receive the lone-pair of electrons from the N2. In addition, the antibonding orbital of the N2 is also back-bonded by the d-orbital electron. As a result, the inert NN chemical bond is successfully activated for the subsequent e-NRR reactions. This process is called as the “acceptance-donation” mechanism [6,57], which is believed to be the main reason for the weakened N ≡ N bonding. As shown in Fig. 1(c, d), compared with SACs, due to the empty d orbitals of the double-metal sites, DACs can pull out two lone pairs of electrons at both ends of N2, maximizing the activation of N2 molecules. There are mainly four criteria for NRR catalysts with excellent performance (Fig. 1e): (1) The binding energy of the catalyst is negative (Eb<0 eV). Negative indicates that the structure is stable, (2) The adsorption capacity for N2 molecules is strong enough for activation (Eads<−0.3 eV), (3) The dominant reaction is NRR process instead of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), (4) The free energy barrier of the potential-determining step (PDS) is low. As shown in Fig. 2 , the model was based on a phosphorene 4 × 4 supercell with the two-dimensional surface embedded in hybrid N atoms, which was intended to better stabilize metal-substrate interaction. Then, in the central position, we performed anchoring of the homo-nuclear or hetero-nuclear TM atoms at specific sites. To evaluate the stability of the different TM1TM1@N4-P and TM1TM2@N4-P configurations, we calculated their binding energies (Eb) and cohesive energies (Ecoh), respectively (Fig. 3 a). The calculation results showed that their binding energies were −13.39 eV∼ −9.86 eV, which were stronger than the cohesive energies of their corresponding TM1TM1 and TM1TM2 atoms. This indicates that TM1TM1 and TM1TM2 atoms have strong bonding with N4-P, which can be uniformly embedded in N4-P with no aggregation into clusters. As shown in Fig. 3b, For TM1TM1@N4-P configurations, we considered two adsorption sites: (1) TTM1 site (top of TM1 atom), (2) B1 site (bridge site of TM1-TM1 bond). For TM1TM2@N4-P configurations, we considered three adsorption sites, (1) TTM1 site (top of TM1 atom), (2) TTM2 site (top of TM2 atom), (3) B2 site (bridge site of TM1-TM2 bond). As we know, the adsorption stability of the side-on configuration on the catalyst surface is a prerequisite for enzymatic- way reaction. As shown in Fig. S1, we let N2 adsorbed on the surface of the remaining nine catalysts as side-on configurations. After full relaxation, we found that the side-on configuration could stably have adsorbed on the only four catalysts, i.e., NiNi@N4-P, RuRu@N4-P, FeCo@N4-P, NiRu@N4-P. Tables S1 and S2 list the adsorption energies of N2 adsorption at different sites on TM1TM1@N4-P and TM1TM2@N4-P, respectively. The adsorption energies of N2 at the optimal sites and the numbers of electron transfers are shown in (Fig. 3(c, d)). Except for CoRu@N4-P, the adsorption energies of the remaining catalytic sites are all negative, indicating the exothermic adsorption process (Fig 3c). For the CoRu@N4-P system, no matter the N2 molecule is adsorbed with end-on or side-on configuration, the CoRu@N4-P dual-site is not able to fix N2 very well. Therefore, CoRu@N4-P is excluded firstly from the further studies. From the results, it is clear that the N2 molecule prefers the adsorption configuration of end-on with the N2 adsorption energies ranging from −0.30 eV to −1.33 eV (Fig. 3c) and the electron transfer numbers ranging from 0.2 e to 0.47 e (Fig. 3d). Additionally, Table S3 lists the two N2 adsorption configurations on different catalysts with NN bond lengths ranging from 1.132 Å to 1.201 Å. Together with the screening criteria, we further considered e-NRR catalytic candidates with adsorption energies less than −0.30 eV to capture N2 molecule via stabilized chemisorption. 3.2 Mechanism of NRR reaction The N2 reduction, N2 + 6H+ + 6e− → 2NH3, involves six net coupled proton and electron transfer (CPET) steps [8,52,55,58]. As shown in Fig. 4 , within each step is the coupling of a proton with an electron transferred from solution to the adsorbed species on the surface of the catalyst substrate. With the intensive study of N2 reduction, the reaction mechanisms of N2 reduction are becoming increasingly visible in current studies, i.e., distal, alternating and enzymatic pathways [7,59]. For the enzymatic pathway, the two N atoms are also alternately hydrogenated by proton-electron pairs. For the distal pathway, the proton-electron pair continuously hydrogenates the distal N atom of N2 until the NN bond is broken, releasing the first NH3 molecule, and the second NH3 in a similar hydrogenated form. In the case of the alternating pathway, the proton-electron pair alternately hydrogenates the two N atoms in the N2 molecule, producing NH3 in the fifth protonation step. Referring back to the above premise of the NRR process, after satisfying the structural stability and determining the chemisorption mode of N2 molecules, we next need to determine that the dominant reaction is NRR rather than HER. Generally, for eligible electrocatalysts for the NRR, there is a key intermediate process change (stable to instable transition) in the overall N2 reduction [52], beyond N2 adsorption, i.e., *N2+H ++e − →*N2H. As a result, this hydrogenation step affects the entire chemical reaction of the NRR. Due to the existence of two different adsorption ways of N2 molecules, they were analyzed separately. The free energies of HER vs. NRR in Fig. 5 (a) show that the HER will only dominant in RuRu@N4-P as the competing reaction. This system is excluded for the following study firstly. For the remaining configurations, the free energies of N2 after the first step hydrogenation were calculated (Fig. 5b). For NiNi@N4-P, FeCo@N4-P, NiRu@N4-P, the free energies of their first hydrogenation step are 0.84 eV, 0.85 eV, 0.96 eV, respectively, which are much higher than screening criteria of 0.55 eV above and will not be considered for subsequent work. For the end-on configurations, the calculation results show that all the end-on configurations NRR are dominant (Fig. 5c). Fig. 5d shows that the Δ G of first hydrogenation for these nine configurations. Only NiNi@N4-P and FeRu@N4-P meet screening criteria with the Δ G less than 0.55 eV. Ultimately, for NiNi@N4-P and FeRu@N4-P, the subsequent NRR mechanism is considered more likely to occur in terms of the distal or alternating pathway. Fig. 6 shows the free energy pathways of NRR for these two systems with the corresponding reaction intermediates shown in Figs. 7 and S2. As shown in Fig. 6(a, b), for NiNi@N4-P, we calculated the complete hydrogenation process of N2 through distal (Fig. 6a) and alternating (Fig. 6b) pathways. The first step of hydrogenation has an uphill free energy of 0.43 eV, while the length of the NN is stretched by 6% (Fig. S2a), The subsequent hydrogenations *NNH+H ++e −→*NNH2 and *NNH+H ++e −→*NHNH for distal and alternating pathways have uphill free energy of 0.67 eV and 1.08 eV, respectively. The lower energy barrier indicates that the reaction prefers the distal pathway to proceed. With subsequent hydrogenation, until the second NH3 is formed on the surface of the catalyst, the reaction is spontaneous. The previous studies [56,58] demonstrate that in the acidic medium, further hydrogenation of the *NH3 species is very likely to occur to form NH4 + species that attach to the catalyst surface. Therefore, the generated potential barrier appears to be negligible. The PDS of NH3 formation is the process *NNH+H ++e −→*NNH2 on the distal pathway of NiNi@N4-P with an energy barrier Δ G of 0.67 eV. Similar to NiNi@N4-P, we calculated all the paths of FeRu@N4-P under distal and alternating pathway (Fig. 6 (c, d)). As shown in Fig. 6c, until the first NH3 is released, *N2+H ++e −→*NNH, *NNH+H ++e −→*NH2 both have uphill free energy of 0.45 eV and 0.13 eV, respectively. In addition, the length of NN is further elongated (from 1.135 Å to 1.212 Å to 1.274 Å) (Fig. S2b). In the subsequent hydrogenation process, until the second NH3 molecule is generated, only the energy barrier of 0.45 eV needs to be overcome. The PDS of the FeRu@N4-P distal pathway is 0.45 eV. For FeRu@N4-P, under the alternating pathway (Fig. 6d), *NNH is the first intermediate of NRR and its formation has an uphill energy of 0.45 eV. As shown in Fig. 7(a, b) the bond length of NN is stretched from 1.135 Å to 1.212 Å with the elongation rate of 6.9%. Further hydrogenation produces *NHNH, the bond length of NN is further stretched from 1.212 Å to 1.265 Å with the elongation rate of 4.4% (Fig. 7c) and the free energy is uphill with 0.52 eV. The subsequent hydrogenation process, all are with downhill energies of −0.20 eV, −0.68 eV, −1.79 eV, −0.09 eV, respectively. Moreover, we notice that there is a transformation from the alternating pathway to the enzymatic pathway for the step *NH2 NH2 + H+ + e− →*NH2+*NH3 and a weak bonding exists between the firstly formed NH3 and the adsorbent, which usually does not exist in the distal and alternating paths (Fig. 7e, f). Because the protonation process in the second step, *NNH+H ++e −→*NHNH overcomes the energy barrier as high as 0.52 eV, this step affects the entire reaction process which is treated as the PDS. Therefore, on the FeRu@N4-P catalyst, the NRR process The NRR process may have two possibilities (distal and alternating pathway), due to the small difference in PDS between them. In Table 1 , we list the overpotentials of each catalyst in this work and compare it with previous studies [28,33,60,61]. The overpotentials of NiNi@N4-P (distal pathway) and FeRu@N4-P (distal pathway) were 0.51 V and 0.29 V, respectively. Compared with the reported works, they present lower overpotentials than those of B-B1P (0.62 V), B-B (0.76 V) and Ru1@C2N (0.78 V) but still higher than those of CuRu@N4-BP (0.14 V) and Ru/Boron (0.26 V), In particular, the FeRu@N4-P shows very competitive catalytic efficiency with the overpotential of 0.29 V. 3.3 Electronic analysis The assessment of the catalytic reduction performance of N2 highlights the potential advantages of NiNi@N4-P and FeRu@N4-P as the e-NRR catalyst. Further analysis of the electronic structure properties explores the essentiality of the activation of N2. We calculated their corresponding charge density differences (CDD). As shown in the light yellow and cyan regions in Fig. 8 , it reveals the aggregation and depletion during charge transfer between the N2 molecules and the catalyst. Most of the charge transfer provided on the catalyst tends to aggregate near the proximal N atom of the N2, so that there is a depletion of charge between the two N atoms and the chemical bonding is weakened. In addition, using the Bader charge analysis, the number of charges transferred from the catalyst to the N2 is approximately 0.21 e, 0.24 e, respectively. To further understand the interaction mechanism between the N2 and the catalyst surface from the chemical bond. Density of states (DOS), a way of describing orbital hybridization, is used to explain the change of N2 before and after adsorption on the catalyst surface. As shown in Fig. 9 a, we firstly calculate the partial density of states (PDOS) of FeRu@N4-P. As is well known, the inactivity of the NN bond in the N2 molecule, is mainly due to the π anti-bond (π*) in the orbitals, and therefore, reducing the π* is one of the strategies for efficient activation of the N2 molecule. This activation is achieved by using d-orbital electrons in the valence shell of TMs to contribute to the π*, and has been demonstrated in numerous studies. Thus, the valence shell orbital Fe and Ru dual-atom synergistically have great potential to activate π* in N2 molecules. As the N2 molecule is adsorbed to FeRu@N4-P with the end-on configuration, significant orbital splitting occurs near the Fermi-level as depicted in Fig. 9b. This splitting indicates a weakening of the energy of the π* in N2 and the formation of d-π* orbitals hybridization with the d orbital of Fe and Ru atoms, which in turn activates the inert N2, causing a 6.78% stretch in the NN chemical bond length at that time. Furthermore, in the energy range −10 eV to −5 eV, the d orbitals of the unoccupied Fe and Ru accept electrons from the bonding orbitals (i.e., and π) of the N2 molecule and contribute positively to the activation of the inert N2 to some extent as well. As shown in Fig. S3, for NiNi@N4-P, we also calculated its PDOS. Similar to the FeRu@N4-P, the PDOS for NiNi@N4-P present similar orbitals hybridization. The strong d-π* orbital hybridization plays a key role in the activation of N2 on the surface. 3.4 Stability of catalyst in DFT-MD By evaluating catalytic performance serially, we predicted the possibility of potentially high-performance e-NRR catalysts for FeRu@N4-P. However, the ability of the catalysts to remain stable and persistent at room temperature conditions is important for practical catalyst operation. Therefore, with the help of DFT-MD calculations, the temperature and energy versus time are shown in Fig. 10 . Apparently, both the temperature and the energy vs. time remain stability for a time period of 5 ps. The excellent stability of FeRu@N4-P provides strong support for the experimental synthesis under room temperature conditions. 3.5 A simple descriptor to predict the NRR activity In addition, the Gibbs free energy of N2 adsorption (ΔG*N2) on the catalyst surface has been recognized as a key parameter that can be used to roughly evaluate NRR activity. As shown in Fig. 11 a, except for the FeNi@N4-P, NiNi@N4-P, NiRu@N4-P, the length of the N N bond shows a linear relationship as a function of the ΔG*N2 with the square of correlation coefficient R2 = 0.871 and the bond length increases with the decrease of the ΔG*N2, which means that the strong adsorption of the N2 can facilitate the activation of the N N bond. In addition, another descriptor Φ, defined as the product of valence electron number (Nd) and the electronegativity (EM) of the metal [62], is used to investigate the its correlation with the ΔG*N2. Different from the previous SAC, the descriptor of Φ for DAC is defined as a geometric average: (8) Φ = ( N d 1 × E TM 1 ) × ( N d 2 × E TM 2 ) where Nd1, Nd2 are the valence numbers of electrons for the two metals of DAC and ETM1, ETM2 are the electronegativities for the two metals of DAC, respectively. As shown in Fig. 11b, except for NiRu@N4-P, the remaining catalysts have a quasi-linear relationship with the square of correlation coefficient R2 = 0.588. This R2 = 0.588 is much smaller than those previously reported (R2= 0.851, 0.842) for the SACs [17,63] indicating the linear relationship is not as good as that of SACs. This may be attributed to the non-unique adsorption sites and the synergy effects of the DAC. 4 Conclusion In summary, we designed a number of various homo-nuclear and hetero-nuclear DACs based on reliable DFT for the purpose of high performance electrocatalytic N2 reduction. Based on the screening strategy, two systems of NiNi@N4-P and FeRu@N4-P were firstly screened out as the candidates of the NRR catalyst because they exhibited lower limiting potentials for the first protonation step *N2→*N2H. The full energy paths of the reaction show that the distal and alternating pathways occur on the FeRu@N4-P with the lowest overpotential (only 0.29 and 0.36 V). In addition, we notice that there is a transformation from the alternating pathway to the enzymatic pathway for the step *NH2 NH2 + H+ + e− →*NH2+*NH3 and a weak bonding exists between the firstly formed NH3 and the adsorbent, which usually does not exist in the distal and alternating paths. The electronic analysis of PDOS reveals the hybridization of the d orbitals of the FeRu atoms and the p orbital of N2, and that electron transfer serves a key role in weakening the inert NN bond. Subsequently, we demonstrated the stability of FeRu@N4-P by performing DFT-MD simulation at room temperature. Finally, the quasi-linear correlation between ΔG*N2 and dual-atom N4-P were described by Φ. This theoretic study will deepen our insights on the e-NRR mechanism on the dual-atom doped phosphorene and advance the further experimental exploration of homo-nuclear or hetero-nuclear DACs in the two-dimensional nanomaterials for the N2 fixation. coredata.dc:description: The highly efficient electrochemical synthesis of ammonia is regarded as a promising alternative compared to the traditional Haber-Bosch (H-B) process. However, the high-activity, low-cost, and long-term stability of electrocatalysts are still barriers to their rapid development. Herein, utilizing density functional theory (DFT), FeRu dual-atom catalyst anchored in N-doped phosphorene (FeRu@N4-P) is developed as a potential candidate for reducing inert N2 through electrocatalysis. Our results reveal that the distal and alternating pathways occur on the FeRu@N4-P with the lowest overpotential (0.29 V and 0.36 V). Moreover, we notice that there is a transformation from the alternating pathway to the enzymatic pathway for the step *NH2 NH2 + H+ + e− →*NH2+*NH3. Considering the influence of the electrolyte solution in the actual experiment, we compared the sensitivity of electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (e-NRR) catalyst to the adsorption of H, demonstrating the efficient selectivity of FeRu@N4-P. The catalysts still maintain good stability and performance at room temperature. Finally, combining the physical properties of the metal atom, Φ is chosen to as the descriptor linearly correlating to the ΔG*N2 on the catalyst. This study deepens our understanding on the e-NRR mechanism on the dual-atoms doped phosphorene and opens a new way for the design of catalyst of the N2 fixation.
coredata.dc:title: Electrocatalytic reduction of N2 on FeRu dual-atom catalyst anchored in N-doped phosphorene
